thesis_damage_flags.why: Negative headline: NIH stopped a Johnson & Johnson blood thinner drug arm in a stroke trial after safety review (2026-02-11, Benzinga).
Negative headline: Russia moves to block WhatsApp and threatens Meta with permanent ban (2026-02-12, Benzinga).

thesis: Risk-management trim: JNJ has fresh clinical/safety headline risk (NIH stopping a trial after safety review) that can pressure sentiment over a 30-day horizon.
Reallocate modestly away from idiosyncratic pharma trial-risk toward broader Quality+Momentum exposures with fewer single-asset binary catalysts.
Keeps Health Care exposure while reducing concentrated thesis fragility.
risks: Headline may prove immaterial to fundamentals and the stock could rebound, making the trim opportunity-costly.
Health Care defensiveness could be in demand; trimming reduces ballast if risk-off resumes.
Subsequent company updates could clarify/mitigate the issue, reversing the signal.
falsifiable_checks: If follow-on reporting indicates the halted study is minor/non-core (no meaningful revenue/probability-of-success impact), the 'thesis damage' signal weakens.
If additional safety/regulatory actions emerge (additional trial halts, broader restrictions), the downside-risk case strengthens and further de-risking may be warranted.
trade_of_the_day.why_now: 12–18 months: maintain Quality+Momentum while avoiding avoidable idiosyncratic drawdowns; clinical/regulatory headlines can create asymmetric near-term volatility that degrades momentum, so a small trim improves portfolio robustness without exiting the sector.
trade_of_the_day.position_sizing_suggestion_within_constr: Trim JNJ by 2% weight (from 8% to 6%) and reallocate +1% to MSFT and +1% to CAT.
